Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Salt Rock Microstructure and Deformation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Salt rock is used for secure storage of oil, high-pressure gas, and nuclear waste because of its ability to creep and form barriers to gas and fluid flow. However, creep processes near subsurface storage facilities can lead to crack debonding, opening, closure and rebonding that compromise the integrity of flow barriers and stability of engineered structures. Mathematical descriptions of cracking and healing are incompletely developed. This award will support fundamental rock physics and mechanics research to link deformation by crack debonding, opening and rebonding to microstructures and mechanical variables that govern the time-dependent behavior of salt rock over geological space and time scales. Deformation of salt occurs rapidly at laboratory conditions making it a good analog to study damage and healing in other crystalline materials and porous media. Project findings are expected to advance quantitative relations enabling accurate modeling and prediction of behaviors in engineering projects. The work will advance fundamental understanding of cracking and healing in other rocks that deform by the same processes, especially around earthquake faults and zones of induced seismicity. The team of geoscience and engineering researchers will collaborate with other programs to broaden the participation of women and other under-represented groups in research and engineering.

Most continuum damage models for salt are based on the concept of dilatancy boundary, and do not account for crack-induced anisotropy of elastic properties. Micro-mechanics and homogenization principles were successfully employed to model salt rock elastoplastic behavior, but were not used to test scale invariance of microstructure to transitions in deformation regimes. The goal of this project is to link salt deformation regimes and rheological behaviors with the density and orientation distribution of microstructures. Deformation regimes at the scale of a Representative Elementary Volume will be decomposed into independent processes (e.g., cracking), each related to different microstructure descriptors (e.g., grain aspect ratio). Macroscopic thermodynamic variables will be formally related to the microstructure descriptors to test the space and time scale invariance of transition points in deformation regimes. Specific research objectives are to: (1) Identify topological components and subcomponents of salt microstructure; (2) Determine the energy cost of intra- and inter-granular crack debonding, opening, closure and rebonding; (3) Compute energy thresholds associated with transitions between deformation regimes at the grain and REV scales; (4) Test the time and scale dependence of microstructure organization during transitions; (5) Design rock salt microstructural systems that optimize healing properties in subsurface storage environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research work aims to understand the chemo-mechanical processes that control the behavior of salt rock, a geomaterial that can naturally self-heal by crack rebonding under favorable temperature, moisture and stress conditions. A novel experiment was designed, set up and calibrated to characterize granular salt creep behavior under controlled conditions of temperature, moisture and stress. The set up was utilized for testing salt granular assemblies with various grain size distributions and quartz volumetric fractions. Informed by microstructure images acquired on granular salt assemblies and on synthetic salt rock tested at Texas A&M, we formulated three types of models to couple microstructure evolution to macroscopic damage and healing mechanical behavior: microstructure-enriched damage and healing mechanics, self-consistent inclusion/matrix models, and Joint-enriched Finite Element Methods (JFEM).

 

Intellectual Merit

In this project, by contrast with most continuum damage models proposed for salt, damage-induced anisotropy is modeled in both deformation and stiffness. A set of independent topological descriptors is determined from statistical image analysis to characterize microstructure evolution upon rock damage and healing. A fabric tensor is introduced in a continuum mechanics model to predict the coupled evolution of microstructure and macroscopic mechanical properties of anisotropic, pre-textured rock. Deformation rates, mechanical damage and stiffness recovery are determined experimentally to both inform and calibrate this fabric-enriched continuum damage mechanics model. Creep tests on granular mixtures also show that the presence of quartz impurities induces sequential pore collapse and delayed pressure solution.

Previous micro-mechanics and homogenization principles were not used to assess the scale at which microstructure changes should be tracked (e.g. sub-crystal, crystal or polycrystal scale) to predict transitions in deformation regimes. In this study, we compare a self-consistent inclusion/matrix model of viscous damage in salt polycrystals to a joint-enriched Finite Element Method that predicts explicit crack patterns at multiple scales. Numerical simulations confirm the occurrence of force chains parallel to the loading axis and the development of stress concentrations at the contact between angular grains.

Halite may be viewed as a model material to study the fundamental microscopic processes leading to macroscopic mechanical recovery in cracked-crystalline and porous-granular materials, which is expected to bring new insights in geomechanics, geology and material sciences. For instance, the same concepts and variables as those used in the fabric-enriched models, matrix/inclusion homogenization schemes and Joint-enriched Finite Element Method could be used to optimize the design of self-healing cement-based materials and ceramics. In general, the pressing needs for energy efficient manufacturing methods and sustainable infrastructure increase interest for theoretical research on damage and healing, which falls in the scope of the White House Material Genome Initiative.

 

 


 

Broader Impacts

An interdisciplinary collaboration was built between experimental geophysicists at Texas A&M and geomechanics modelers at Georgia Tech, who interacted with researchers and students from several European research institutions. At Georgia Tech, the project involved one faculty (Arson, PI), two PhD students, one visiting MSc student from The Netherlands, two visiting undergraduate students from France, and fourteen undergraduate students from all majors of the College of Engineering. Three Georgia Tech students did an internship in France as part of the project. Dr. Arson also hosted two European faculty members and visited 3 European research institutions to launch long-term collaborations on microstructure enriched continuum damage mechanics and numerical modeling of texture development. One PhD student appointed on this project graduated, and is now an Assistant Professor at Rowan University.

A wikipage and a website are regularly updated with new results. Since the beginning of the project, findings have been disseminated in academic publications, including four journal papers (three published, one under review), eleven conference papers (published), three conference abstracts (two published, one under review), one Ph.D. thesis (Georgia Tech, 2016) and one MSc thesis (University of Utrecht, The Netherlands, 2015). Dr. Arson gave eight invited lectures related to the project: four in the U.S., and four in Europe.

Project findings are expected to advance knowledge on deep geological storage systems, such as cavities used to store high-pressure gas, and self-healing deep repositories for hazardous waste disposals. Thermo-mechanical simulations of cavern pressurization and depressurization evidenced the significant influences of idle time, gas pressure range, and injection and withdrawal cycles on stress, strain and temperature distributions in the vicinity of the cavern. The combined use of microstructure-enriched continuum damage and healing mechanics, self-consistent inclusion/matrix models and JFEM provides a flexible framework to design large scale storage facilities with efficient Finite Element models, informed by micro-macro models that can predict the local occurrence of textures and stress concentrations. The proposed models will also be applicable for predicting fault rupture during earthquakes, because tectonic events in the silicate crust originate cyclic loading, fatigue and healing processes that are similar to those encountered in geological storage systems.
